Journal.Title: The Science of the total environment

Article.ArticleTitle: Short-term exposure to air pollution and infant mortality: A systematic review and meta-analysis.

AbstractText: Infant mortality is a widely reported indicator of population health and a leading public health concern. In this systematic review and meta-analysis, we review the available literature for epidemiologic evidence of the association between short-term air pollution exposure and infant mortality.

Relevant publications were identified through PubMed and Web of Science databases using comprehensive search terms and screened using predefined inclusion/exclusion criteria. We extracted data from included studies and applied a systematic rubric for evaluating study quality across domains including participant selection, outcome, exposure, confounding, analysis, selective reporting, sensitivity, and overall quality. We performed meta-analyses, using both fixed and random-effect methods, and estimated pooled odds ratios (ORs) and 95 % confidence intervals (95%CI) for pollutants (nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub>), sulfur dioxide (SO<sub>2</sub>), coarse particulate matter (PM<sub>10</sub>), fine particulate matter (PM<sub>2.5</sub>), ozone (O<sub>3</sub>), carbon monoxide (CO)) and infant mortality, neonatal mortality, or postneonatal mortality.

Our search returned 549 studies. We excluded 490 studies in the abstract screening phase and an additional 37 studies in the full text screening phase, leaving 22 studies for inclusion. Among these 22 studies, 14 included effect estimates for PM<sub>10</sub>, 13 for O<sub>3</sub>, 11 for both NO<sub>2</sub> and CO, 8 for SO<sub>2</sub>, and 3 for PM<sub>2.5</sub>. We did not calculate a pooled OR for PM<sub>2.5</sub> due to the limited number of studies available and demonstrated heterogeneity in the effect estimates. The pooled ORs (95%CI) with the greatest magnitudes were for a 10-ppb increase in SO<sub>2</sub> or NO<sub>2</sub> concentration in the days before death (1.07 [95%CI: 1.02, 1.12], 1.04 [95%CI: 1.01, 1.08], respectively). The pooled OR for PM<sub>10</sub> was 1.02 (95%CI: 1.00, 1.03), and the pooled ORs for CO and O<sub>3</sub> were 1.01 (95%CI: 1.00, 1.02) and 0.99 (95%CI: 0.97, 1.01).
Increased exposure to SO<sub>2</sub>, NO<sub>2</sub>, PM<sub>10</sub>, or CO is associated with infant mortality across studies.
